newsitem.title: USA: IMM currency futures end mixed, yen off, pound up.
newsitem.headline: IMM currency futures end mixed, yen off, pound up.

text.p: IMM currency futures finished mixed, with March yen and Swiss franc each setting new contract lows while sterling surged to sharp gains and a new contract high.
Traders attributed the divergence between yen and sterling partly to cross activity on interest rate differentials.
They cited perceptions that Japan's sputtering economy could not withstand a rate hike, even though that might help keep investors attracted to yen-denominated assets.
Conversely, they viewed Britain's economy as robust enough to warrant another inflation-fighting rate rise soon.
March yen continued its overnight erosion and near the close of European trading slumped to its contract low price of $0.008690.
The dollar hurdled 116.00 yen and hit a ceiling at 116.20 during North American hours as March yen futures slightly overshot $0.008695, which roughly corresponds to 116.20.
Some brokers noted signs the some players who were short dollars from 113.00 were finally squaring up before year-end.
"Everybody's who was short dollars at 113.00 is getting out," one floor broker of the yen's slide. "It's really just some people getting stuck."

Brokers said one firm was seen selling a couple of hundred March Swiss francs as that unit sagged to another new contract low, this one at $0.7452, at midday on sales against higher-yielding units such as marks and sterling.

March sterling popped up to a new contract high, at 1.6926, with some saying buying traced partly to small fund purchases. One arm of a French-owned bank bought some 2,200 March sterling on the day as that unit jumped, brokers said.
But brokers looked for sterling buyers to turn leery as that contract nears 1.70, with some selling pressure expected to emerge between the 1.70 and 2.00 levels.
Additional weight on currencies stemmed from a rise in U.S. Treasury bond futures coupled with early firming in U.S. stocks, which later erased the bulk of gains.

Futures edged up slightly after much weaker than expected November U.S. durable goods orders, which fell 1.6 percent versus forecasts for a 0.1 percent rise. Ex-defense, orders fell 3.4 percent, well below forecasts for a 0.5 percent fall.

March yen fell $0.000053 to $0.008750, marks eased $0.0001 to $0.6464, Swiss fr lost $0.0028 to $0.7465, sterling rallied $0.0218 to $1.6918, Can dollar lost $0.0026 to $0.7350, Aus dollar up $0.0009 to $0.7949, Mex peso off $0.000050 at $0.121675. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750/E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com))
